contentrichtext.text: {{Italic title}} {{taxobox |name=''Salvia elegans'' |image = Salvia elegans.jpg |image_caption = |regnum = [[Plant]]ae |unranked_divisio = [[Flowering plant|Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]] |ordo = [[Lamiales]] |familia = [[Lamiaceae]] |genus = ''[[Salvia]]'' |species = '''''S. elegans''''' |binomial = ''Salvia elegans'' |binomial_authority = [[Martin Vahl|Vahl]] |synonyms = ''Salvia rutilans'' <small>[[Élie-Abel Carrière|Carrière]]</small> |}} '''''Salvia elegans''''', commonly called '''Pineapple sage''' or '''Tangerine Sage''',<ref>[http://greenwalks.wordpress.com/2008/10/10/tangerine-sage/ Greenwalks: Tangerine Sage]</ref> is a perennial shrub native to [[Mexico]] and [[Guatemala]]. It inhabits [[Madrean pine-oak woodlands|Madrean]] and [[Mesoamerican pine-oak forests]] between {{convert|6000|and|9000|ft|m|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Clebsch">{{cite book|last=Clebsch|first=Betsy|coauthors=Carol D. Barner|title=The New Book of Salvias|publisher=Timber Press|date=2003|pages=115–117|isbn=978-0-88192-560-9|url=http://books.google.com/?id=NM0iwB8GrQYC&pg=PA115&dq=%22salvia+elegans%22}}</ref> ==Description== ''S. elegans'' has tubular red flowers and an attractive scent to the leaves that is similar to pineapple. It produces numerous erect leafy stems and flowers in the late autumn. The red flowers are attractive to [[hummingbird]]s and butterflies. In a highland temperate forest in central Mexico, pineapple sage was found to be one of the three most-visited species by hummingbirds.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Lara|first=Carlos|date=Mar. 2006|title=Temporal dynamics of flower use by hummingbirds in a highland temperate forest in Mexico|journal=Ecoscience|volume=13|issue=1|year=2006|pages=23|doi=10.2980/1195-6860(2006)13[23:TDOFUB]2.0.CO;2}}</ref> It is a [[short-day plant]]. The flowering season in Mexico is August onward; further north it may not flower till later autumn, and if there are no frosts, it may flower till spring. ==Cultivation== In cultivation, Pineapple sage grows to {{convert|1.2|to|1.5|m|ft|abbr=on}} tall, with the roots extending underground to form a large clump. The pale yellow-green leaves are veined, and covered with fine hairs. Six to twelve scarlet flowers grow in whorls, with a long inflorescence that blooms gradually and over a prolonged period of time. With a [[hard frost]], the plant will die down to the ground and grow back the following spring. Pineapple sage was introduced into horticulture about 1870.<ref name="Clebsch"/> The variety "Honey Melon", which has the same pineapple fragrance in the leaves, blooms early in the summer, rather than in autumn.<ref name="Clebsch"/> ==Uses== The leaves and flowers of ''S. elegans'' are edible.<ref>{{cite book |first=Beth |last=Hanson |title=Gourmet Herbs |year=2001 |publisher=Broolyn Botanic Garden |isbn=978-1-889538-21-1 |page=90}}</ref> The plant is extensively used in Mexican traditional medicine, especially for the treatment of anxiety, and also for lowering of blood pressure. Although scientific information about these medicinal properties is scarce, a preliminary study on mice found support for the plant potentially having [[antidepressant]] and [[antianxiety]] properties.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Herrera-Ruiza|first=Maribel|coauthors=Yolanda García-Beltrána, Sergio Morab, Gabriela Díaz-Vélizb, Glauce S.B. Vianac, Jaime Tortorielloa, Guillermo Ramíreza|date=Aug. 2006|title=Antidepressant and anxiolytic effects of hydroalcoholic extract from Salvia elegans|journal=Journal of Ethnopharmacology|volume=107|issue=1|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0378874106000808|doi=10.1016/j.jep.2006.02.003|pmid=16530995}}</ref> Pineapple sage has also been shown to have a dose-dependent [[antihypertensive]] effect, attributed to its action as an [[angiotensin II receptor antagonist]] and inhibitor of the [[angiotensin converting enzyme]].<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Jiménez-Ferrer | first1 = Enrique | last2 = Hernández Badillo | first2 = Fidel | last3 = González-Cortazar | first3 = Manases | last4 = Tortoriello | first4 = Jaime | last5 = Herrera-Ruiz | first5 = Maribel | title = Antihypertensive activity of Salvia elegans Vahl. (Lamiaceae): ACE inhibition and angiotensin II antagonism | doi = 10.1016/j.jep.2010.05.013 | journal = Journal of Ethnopharmacology | volume = 130 | issue = 2 | pages = 340–346 | year = 2010 | pmid = 20488233 | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0378874110003193 }} </ref> ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Salvia elegans}} {{wikispecies}} *[http://www.floridata.com/ref/S/salv_ele.cfm ''S. elegans''] from [http://www.floridata.com/index.cfm Floridata] *[http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=SAEL6 USDA Plants Profile] [[Category:Salvia|elegans]] [[Category:Flora of Mexico]] [[Category:Flora of Guatemala]]
